diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's most common in children under 5 years old. Symptoms go beyond those listed and can include swollen glands and dry, cracked lips.

diagnoses.name: Cellulitis
diagnoses.description: A common and potentially serious bacterial skin infection. The affected skin appears swollen and red and is typically painful and warm to the touch.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial illness that develops in some people who have strep throat. It features a bright red rash that covers most of the body, a high fever, and a sore throat.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)
diagnoses.description: An infection in any part of the urinary system, kidneys, bladder, or urethra. Pyuria is a common symptom, as are fever and pain with urination.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body (cross-reactivity). It can cause inflammation of the joints, eyes, or urethra (hence pyuria).

diagnoses.name: Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease
diagnoses.description: A mild, contagious viral infection common in young children, characterized by sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet. It might occasionally cause a fever.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Fever and flu-like symptoms are followed by a painful rash that spreads and blisters.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection transmitted by a tick. Along with fever, headache, and rash, it can cause a distinctive red, spotted rash that spreads.

diagnoses.name: Erysipelas
diagnoses.description: An acute, febrile infectious disease caused by a specific type of streptococcus. It affects the superficial lymphatic system of the skin primarily and is characterized by large, raised red patches on the skin.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP)
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause rash, abdominal pain, and joint inflammation. It is often preceded by an infection, such as a throat infection.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: A highly contagious viral infection causing fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and characteristic red, spotty rash.

diagnoses.name: Rubella
diagnoses.description: A contagious viral disease characterized by fever, sore throat, rash, and possible birth defects if contracted during pregnancy.

diagnoses.name: Dengue fever
diagnoses.description: A mosquito-transmitted virus causing high fever, rash, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, and muscle and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Zika virus infection
diagnoses.description: A disease caused by the Zika virus, spread by mosquitoes, causing mild fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and in some cases, neurological complications.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet fever
diagnoses.description: An infectious bacterial illness that develops in some people with strep throat, characterized by a bright red rash, fever, and sore throat.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome is a chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the HIV virus which damages the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Gonococcal infection
diagnoses.description: A sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, often resulting in discharge and inflammation at the infection site, and can lead to more severe complications if left untreated.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever, causing fever, joint pain, and rash.

diagnoses.name: Ross River fever
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease spread by mosquito bites, causing fever, rash, and debilitating joint pains.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect kidneys (lupus nephritis), cause fever, lead to pleuritis and pleural effusion, result in acute pericarditis, and create skin manifestations such as an annular rash.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can cause acute pericarditis, lead to nephritis, induce fever, and result in pleural effusion. Rash can also appear in certain viral illnesses.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.rationale: Rheumatic fever, which follows untreated strep throat, can lead to fever, rash, and inflammation of the heart including pericarditis. While less common, it can result in nephritis and involves pleural effusion in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease can lead to symptoms such as nephritis, fever, pleuritis with effusion, acute pericarditis, and skin rashes including annular types.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Drug-induced lupus can present with symptoms similar to SLE, including fever, pleural effusion, acute pericarditis, nephritis, and rash. It is usually caused by certain medications.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis may present with fever, nephritis due to granuloma formation in the kidneys, pleural effusion, pericarditis, and skin manifestations including erythema nodosum which can appear annular.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Although more commonly associated with heart valve issues, infective endocarditis can lead to fevers, can cause acute pericarditis, and in severe cases, complications may include pleural effusion. Skin manifestations like Osler's nodes can appear rash-like.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behçet's disease can cause vascular inflammation leading to symptoms like fever and rash, with possible kidney involvement (nephritis), and it has been associated with pericarditis and pleural effusions in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.rationale: This infection, caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, can present with fever, rash (initially may appear as small spots that could potentially spread and seem annular), and in severe cases, can involve systemic complications such as kidney failure (nephritis) and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, Lyme disease can present with fever, nephritis, cardiac complications including pericarditis, a characteristic annular rash (erythema migrans), and in advanced stages, can cause pleuritis.

diagnoses: Phenytoin or other antiepileptic drug toxicity
Hepatitis B or C with extrahepatic manifestations
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Hepatitis B or C Related Cryoglobulinemia

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with fever, pleuritis leading to pleural effusion, proteinuria due to lupus nephritis, arthralgia or non-erosive arthritis, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily presenting with joint involvement, rheumatoid arthritis can also manifest systemic features including fever, pericarditis, pleural effusion, and secondary amyloidosis causing proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: In addition to fever, infective endocarditis can cause immune complex deposition, leading to proteinuria and vasculitis that can present as cutaneous or visceral manifestations, including arthropathy. Rarely, it can be associated with pericarditis and pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD can present with overlapping features of several connective tissue diseases including fever, arthropathy, pericarditis, pleural effusion, and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis can present with fever, arthritis (especially Lofgren syndrome), pericarditis, pleural effusion, and kidney involvement leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
diagnoses.rationale: Systemic vasculitis can manifest with fever, arthralgias or arthritis, renal involvement presenting as proteinuria, pericarditis, and pleural effusion due to direct involvement of the vasculature in these areas.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.rationale: Tuberculosis can lead to pleural effusion, fever, proteinuria (from renal involvement), arthropathy (Poncet's disease), and pericarditis (in tuberculous pericarditis).

diagnoses.name: Still's Disease (Adult-Onset Still's Disease or AOSD)
diagnoses.rationale: AOSD is a rare inflammatory disorder that can present with fever, arthralgia or arthritis, pericarditis, and pleuritis. Proteinuria is less common but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behçet's disease can have a wide range of symptoms including fever, arthritis, pericarditis, and, less commonly, pleural effusion and proteinuria due to renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: In late stages, HIV can cause a variety of symptoms including fever, arthropathy, pleural effusion, and proteinuria either due to direct infection or secondary to opportunistic infections or neoplasms that can also cause pericarditis.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (e.g., Coxsackievirus, Parvovirus B19, HIV)

diagnoses.name: Adult-Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inflammatory disorder characterized by the classic triad of persistent high fevers, joint inflammation, and a distinctive salmon-colored bumpy rash. It may also present with additional features such as pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, and maculopapular rash.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect nearly any part of the body, manifesting in a wide range of symptoms including arthritis, skin rashes such as a maculopapular rash, and serositis leading to pleural and pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder affecting children, characterized by persistent arthritis. Some forms may present with systemic features including rash and serositis, potentially leading to pericardial and pleural effusions.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A multisystem granulomatous disease of unknown cause, which commonly affects the lungs, lymph nodes, and skin, resulting in a wide array of manifestations including arthralgia, skin lesions, and pleural effusions.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder with overlapping features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including arthropathy, skin rashes, and pleural/pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In severe cases, it can affect skin, eyes, lungs, heart, and blood vessels, potentially leading to pleural and pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rashes. In some cases, it can be associated with internal manifestations such as pleural and pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium spread by ticks. It can cause a range of symptoms including rash, arthritis, and, in rare cases, cardiac and neurological disorders.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, characterized by joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, along with skin and nail psoriasis. Systemic involvement can include features like pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that primarily attacks the tear and saliva glands, leading to dry eyes and mouth. It can also result in joint pain, skin rashes, and systemic features like pleuritis and pericarditis.

diagnoses: Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B/C, Epstein-Barr virus)
Autoimmune disorders (e.g., alopecia areata with systemic manifestations)
Psychiatric disorders with somatic presentations (e.g., somatic symptom disorder)
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia combined with thrombocytopenia or neutropenia)
Sjögren's Syndrome with neurological and renal involvement
Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (when associated with other autoimmune disorders)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause dyspigmentation, scarring, proteinuria (due to kidney involvement), and in severe cases, CNS involvement leading to delirium. Joint involvement may present as synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease known for its distinctive skin rash, muscle weakness, dyspigmentation, and can involve other systems leading to proteinuria. Joint inflammation could be interpreted as synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases causing hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It can lead to dyspigmentation, atrophic scarring, and may involve the kidneys (proteinuria) and joints (synovitis). Central nervous system involvement is less common but can lead to neuropsychiatric symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While primarily known for synovitis, it can also lead to skin changes (dyspigmentation, rheumatoid nodules) and proteinuria through renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: This disease features a mix of symptoms seen in systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis, including potential for dyspigmentation, atrophic scarring, synovitis, proteinuria, and systemic symptoms that can affect cognitive function.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the kidneys caused by systemic lupus erythematosus, presenting primarily with proteinuria. Other symptoms of systemic lupus can include dyspigmentation, neuropsychiatric symptoms like delirium, and joint issues like synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, noted for its skin rash (which can include changes in pigmentation) and joint inflammation. It can occasionally present with neurological symptoms (such as delirium) in severe cases and could potentially lead to proteinuria through kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: A vasculitis disorder that can cause proteinuria (due to kidney involvement), rashes leading to dyspigmentation, and joint pain, potentially mimicking synovitis. Serious cases can have neurological manifestations, including delirium.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. It can lead to skin changes, including dyspigmentation, atrophic scarring, and can also affect the brain, potentially leading to delirium. Arthritis or synovitis and kidney involvement (proteinuria) are other components.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease that leads to inflammation, usually in your lungs, skin, or lymph nodes. Skin involvement can present as dyspigmentation, and while less common, it can affect the kidneys (proteinuria), nervous system (delirium), and joints (synovitis).

diagnoses: Connective Tissue Diseases (e.g., Rheumatoid Arthritis, Sjögren’s Syndrome)
Cancer (Hematologic, such as Leukemia or Lymphomas)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Schizophrenia (for isolated psychosis, though usually without the other mentioned symptoms)

diagnoses.name: Lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by symptoms like acute pericarditis, pericardial effusion, rash, and potentially alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause systemic symptoms, including rashes, pericarditis, and other cardiovascular issues.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease known for its characteristic skin rash along with muscle weakness. Patients can also experience symptoms related to the heart, such as pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. Skin manifestations like rashes and systemic symptoms including pericardial effusion can occur.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: An infection usually caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). Symptoms can include a maculopapular rash, pericarditis, and occasionally, alopecia due to the body's reaction to the virus.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include an annular rash, known as erythema migrans. Cardiac complications can arise in the later stages, including pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition characterized by changes in the skin, blood vessels, muscles, and internal organs. Skin symptoms include rashes and potential alopecia; it can also affect the heart.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune skin condition that speeds up the life cycle of skin cells, causing red, scaly patches that may be painful. It can also have systemic manifestations including cardiac issues.

diagnoses.name: Drug reactions
diagnoses.description: Certain medications can cause adverse reactions including skin rashes, alopecia, and more rarely, acute pericarditis or pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Mixed connective tissue disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that displays features of three other connective tissue diseases—lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis—along with symptoms such as rashes, alopecia, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can present with widespread systemic manifestations including rash, pericarditis, and pleural effusion. Neurological manifestations such as seizures can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.reasoning: This inflammatory disease follows Streptococcus pyogenes infection, which can lead to rash, pericarditis, and less commonly, seizures due to Sydenham's chorea.

diagnoses.name: Viral infections
diagnoses.reasoning: Several viral infections can present with a combination of rash, pericarditis, and pleural effusion. Seizures can occur, especially in severe cases or in individuals with predisposing factors.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reasoning: This is an inflammatory disease known for its distinctive skin rash and muscle weakness. It can also involve the heart (pericarditis) and lungs (pleural effusion), and in rare cases, seizures may occur.

diagnoses.name: Drug reactions
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain medications can induce a reaction leading to rash, pericarditis, pleural effusion, and occasionally seizures, as part of a hypersensitivity response.

diagnoses.name: Still's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Adult-onset Still's disease is characterized by fever, rash, arthritis, and it can affect various organs leading to pericarditis and pleural effusions. Neurological manifestations like seizures are less common.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: This granulomatous disorder can affect any organ system. It might present with rash, lung involvement (including pleural effusion), heart complications (pericarditis), and neurosarcoidosis can lead to seizures.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: If left untreated, Lyme disease can spread to the joints, heart (causing pericarditis), and nervous system (potentially leading to seizures), along with characteristic rash.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Primarily affecting children, this disease causes inflammation in walls of some blood vessels in the body. It can lead to rash, heart complications (including pericarditis), and rarely, it affects the lungs (pleural effusion) or causes neurological symptoms such as seizures.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.reasoning: This tick-borne disease caused by Rickettsia rickettsii can lead to a distinctive rash, and severe cases may involve pericarditis, pleural effusion, and neurological manifestations including seizures.

Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Evans syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Idiopathic inflammatory myopathies (such as Dermatomyositis or Polymyositis)

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Hyperglycemia is a hallmark symptom, and mood lability can result from fluctuations in blood glucose levels.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by hyperglycemia, easy bruising due to thin skin, and mood changes due to cortisol excess.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.reasoning: Primary condition for seizure disorders. Other symptoms may not be directly related but can occur in individuals with longstanding, poorly controlled epilepsy.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Sinusitis noted in symptoms. Chronic cases can affect overall health, potentially contributing to fatigue and worsening of other conditions.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Includes hyperglycemia as a component. Patients with metabolic syndrome may also display mood lability and are at increased risk for conditions causing easy bruising.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reasoning: While PCOS predominantly affects individuals with ovaries, it can cause hyperglycemia and mood lability. The connection to other symptoms is less direct.

diagnoses.name: Steroid-Induced Diabetes
diagnoses.reasoning: Steroid use can cause hyperglycemia, mood lability, and easy bruising due to thinning skin. It does not directly cause seizure disorders or sinusitis but may exacerbate existing conditions.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: While more commonly associated with hypoglycemia, can impact mood and has indirect links to bruising via skin fragility. Addison's disease does not directly cause seizures or sinusitis.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily an infection of the meninges of the brain, it can cause seizures, may be associated with sinusitis complications, and could indirectly affect glucose metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Mitochondrial Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: These disorders can cause a wide range of symptoms, including seizures and possibly hyperglycemia. The other symptoms are less directly related but could be manifestations of systemic disease.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Autoimmune diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus)
Skin conditions (e.g., Eczema, Psoriasis) leading to alopecia and otitis externa

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can damage any part of the body, including skin, joints, and/or organs inside the body.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, mostly the lungs and lymph glands.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, leading to numerous symptoms including ulcers and skin problems.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: A term for two conditions (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) that are characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that may result in changes to the skin, blood vessels, muscles, and internal organs.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that displays features commonly seen in three other connective tissue diseases: systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It may also have features of rheumatoid arthritis.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory type of arthritis that occurs in some people with psoriasis. This condition affects the joints and areas where tissues attach to bone.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious infectious bacterial disease that mainly affects the lungs.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is a virus that attacks the body's immune system. If HIV is not treated, it can lead to the disease AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome).

diagnoses.name: Kounis Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A type of allergic acute coronary syndrome. It is a confluence of acute coronary syndromes with conditions associated with mast cell activation, including allergic or hypersensitivity, as well as anaphylactic or anaphylactoid insults.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth. The hallmark symptoms are dry eyes and dry mouth, but it can also cause fatigue and joint pain. Liver enzyme abnormalities might be present due to associated liver involvement.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reaction
diagnoses.description: Reactions can range from mild to severe and affect multiple body systems, including the skin, gastrointestinal tract, respiratory system (potentially leading to laryngitis as a secondary complication), and cardiovascular system, which could potentially induce reactions like Kounis syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects blood vessels and can lead to abnormal blood vessel formation (vascular anomalies). It can cause various symptoms, depending on the location of the blood vessel malformations.

diagnoses.name: Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)
diagnoses.description: A condition that might occur after an allogeneic tissue transplant. It can manifest with liver enzyme abnormalities, dry eyes due to damage to the lacrimal glands, and vascular anomalies among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease that slowly destroys the bile ducts in the liver and can lead to abnormal liver enzymes. Dry eyes can be a symptom associated with this condition due to its autoimmune nature.

diagnoses.name: Acute Coronary Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A term used to describe a range of conditions associated with sudden, reduced blood flow to the heart, one of which could be triggered by Kounis syndrome. Laryngitis isn’t directly related but could coexist depending on the causative factor like infection or significant stress.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Dry eyes and abnormal liver enzymes can be manifestations of lupus. Vascular anomalies may also be seen in patients with lupus.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced liver injury
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by prescription medications, over-the-counter drugs, or dietary supplements. It can lead to abnormalities in liver enzymes. The drugs causing liver injury could also potentially lead to laryngitis or dry eyes as side effects.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. In cases involving the liver, it can lead to abnormal liver enzymes. Dry eyes are also a feature due to lacrimal gland involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms including dry eyes and difficulty focusing vision due to its impact on moisture-producing glands. Peripheral neuropathy can also occur in this condition.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease of the central nervous system. It can cause sensory neuropathies and, in some cases, seizures or seizure-like activity. Visual disturbances, including difficulty focusing, are common.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus

Parkinson's Disease – can present with restless legs, difficulty concentrating, blepharospasm, and is associated with altered iron metabolism.

Multiple Sclerosis (MS) – might manifest through difficulty concentrating (cognitive challenges), restless legs, and in some cases, might influence the presentation of symptoms like blepharospasm due to lesions affecting neural pathways.

Iron Deficiency Anemia – paradoxically, individuals with iron overload conditions may also present symptoms similar to those of iron deficiency due to poor iron utilization, explaining restless legs and concentration issues.

Wilson’s Disease – a disorder of copper metabolism that can cause neurological and psychiatric symptoms such as difficulty concentrating, and might also affect iron metabolism leading to hyperferritinemia.

diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder leading to hyperthyroidism, which can manifest with hypersensitivity reactions, osteopenia due to accelerated bone turnover, and can indirectly contribute to dry eyes and even hearing issues through related complications.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While primarily known for its joint symptoms, it can also cause Sjögren's syndrome, resulting in dry eyes, and is associated with osteopenia and occasionally hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.description: An excess of parathyroid hormone in the bloodstream due to hyperactivity of one or more of the parathyroid glands. Commonly causes osteopenia or osteoporosis, and can contribute to symptoms of hyperthyroidism. Dry eyes and hearing loss are less directly related but can be seen in broader complications of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Osteogenesis Imperfecta
diagnoses.description: A genetic bone disorder characterized by fragile bones that break easily. It's not directly related to hyperthyroidism, dry eyes, or hypersensitivity reactions, but patients can present with hearing loss and have a history of multiple fractures or low bone density (osteopenia).

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Though primarily associated with low thyroid function, in complex clinical scenarios, patients could transition between hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism (e.g., Hashimoto's thyroiditis fluctuating phases). Symptoms can include hearing loss and, less commonly, dry eyes. Hypersensitivity reactions and osteopenia are less directly associated but may appear in the disease spectrum.

diagnoses.name: Paget's Disease of Bone
diagnoses.description: A disorder that disrupts the replacement of old bone tissue with new bone tissue. While it's more commonly associated with bone pain and bone deformities, it can result in secondary osteopenia or osteoporosis and hearing loss due to involvement of the skull. Links to dry eyes and hyperthyroidism are indirect.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. While not directly causing dry eyes, hyperthyroidism, or hypersensitivity reactions, its complex symptomatology can overlap with several conditions that do.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can widely vary and may include sensory problems and autonomic disturbances that could be linked to dry eyes and hearing loss. It is less directly associated with hyperthyroidism, osteopenia, and hypersensitivity reactions but can coexist with or mimic aspects of these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. Symptoms are varied but can include reactions that mimic hypersensitivity reactions, and secondarily induce conditions leading to dry eyes, osteopenia, and less commonly, hearing loss. Association with hyperthyroidism can be indirect, such as through autoimmune thyroiditis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.rationale: Bronchitis is a common symptom or precursor to COPD, especially if it's chronic bronchitis.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.rationale: Anemia and its symptoms could result from chronic inflammation or chronic diseases.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.rationale: Conditions like lupus or rheumatoid arthritis can lead to systemic issues that might explain the combination of symptoms, including anemia and osteopenia.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D Deficiency
diagnoses.rationale: Lack of vitamin D can contribute to osteopenia and has been linked to chronic diseases including some urinary tract issues.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Diabetes can lead to complications affecting vision (difficulty focusing) and contribute to chronic conditions like osteopenia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.rationale: MS can cause vision problems due to optic neuritis and might indirectly be related to osteopenia through decreased mobility.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease can lead to osteopenia and potentially influence the development of anemia.

diagnoses.name: Interstitial Cystitis/Painful Bladder Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This condition is directly named as a symptom and can be associated with chronic pain and systemic issues.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disease that often features systemic symptoms including chronic inflammation that can affect various organs and lead to symptoms like dry eyes (potentially affecting vision).

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.rationale: Thyroid diseases can lead to a wide range of systemic symptoms, including anemia and impact on vision. The condition can also affect bone density.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken the blood, leading to sluggish blood flow and can cause a variety of symptoms including headaches, dizziness, and itching. It might also contribute to symptoms like dyspepsia and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where stomach contents come back up into the esophagus resulting in either symptoms or complications. Symptoms include the taste of acid in the back of the mouth, heartburn, bad breath, chest pain, vomiting, breathing problems, and wearing away of the teeth.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects blood vessels and can cause excessive bleeding. It is characterized by direct connections between arteries and veins with no capillaries in between. Symptoms can include epistaxis, dyspepsia (due to gastrointestinal telangiectasia), and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It’s characterized by hypermobility of the joints. Some types of EDS may also affect blood vessel integrity, potentially leading to an increased risk of bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.description: An open sore that develops on the inside lining of your stomach (gastric ulcer) or the upper part of your small intestine (duodenal ulcer). Symptoms include stomach pain, nausea, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder caused by low levels or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, a protein that is necessary for blood clotting. Symptoms can include excessive bleeding, such as prolonged nosebleeds, bleeding gums, and bleeding from small cuts or injuries.

diagnoses.name: Gastritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation, irritation, or erosion of the lining of the stomach. It can occur suddenly (acute) or gradually (chronic). Symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and a feeling of fullness in the upper abdomen after eating.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body’s connective tissue. People with Marfan syndrome tend to be tall, with long arms, legs, fingers, and toes. They also typically have flexible joints and scoliosis. The condition can affect the blood vessels, heart, eyes, bones, and other organs.

diagnoses.name: Portal Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A condition of the liver that causes hypertension in the portal venous system and can lead to symptoms like vomiting blood due to the rupture of varices. This condition could indirectly lead to symptoms such as dyspepsia.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: A disorder that can lead to easy or excessive bruising and bleeding. The bleeding results from unusually low levels of platelets — the cells that help blood clot.

diagnoses.explanation: Angioedema is a common manifestation, and symptoms like bloating can result from food allergies.
A genetic disorder causing recurrent episodes of severe swelling. While it doesn't directly cause all listed symptoms, its primary symptom is angioedema.
This condition involves inappropriate mast cell activation and can explain a wide range of symptoms, including bloating, pain, and possibly hyperactivity due to systemic reactions.
Though primarily affecting the bowel, IBS can cause bloating and has been associated with a wide range of non-GI symptoms due to its potential systemic effects.
Several autoimmune disorders can cause symptoms like oral pain (lupus, Sjogren’s syndrome), and systemic inflammation could potentially lead to interstitial cystitis.
Some medications can cause angioedema, oral pain, and other symptoms. Evaluating current medications is important.
While not true allergies, intolerances can also cause symptoms like bloating and angioedema.
Stress and anxiety can manifest physically, causing symptoms like hyperactivity and exacerbating conditions like interstitial cystitis.
Certain deficiencies can cause oral pain and other symptoms, although they might not fully explain the angioedema.
Conditions like thyroid disorders can lead to a range of systemic symptoms, potentially including those listed.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Diabetes Mellitus – considering the symptoms of hyperglycemia and ulcers, which could be indicative of poor wound healing associated with diabetes.
Asthma – given the symptom of wheezing, asthma could be a contributing condition.
Chronic Granulomatous Disease – decreased immunoglobulins and recurrent infections might point towards an underlying issue with the immune system.
Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type I – presenting with candidiasis, hypoparathyroidism, and adrenal insufficiency; it could also explain ulcers and immune abnormalities.

Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID) – given the decreased immunoglobulins suggesting an immune system disorder that could lead to increased susceptibility to infections including those leading to ulcers.
Hyper-IgE Syndrome (Job's Syndrome) – with symptoms of dermatographism potentially being related, alongside an immune dysfunction.
Diabetes Mellitus Type 1 or Type 2 - Hyperglycemia directly hints at diabetes, which could also explain some of the other symptoms through complications or associated conditions.
Selective IgA Deficiency – the most common primary immunodeficiency that could elucidate decreased levels of immunoglobulins, making one prone to infections.
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) – considering the range of symptoms, SLE could be a potential diagnosis, as it’s known to affect multiple body systems including the skin and immune system.

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome – though less common, the presence of eczema (dermatographism could be a related symptom), decreased immunoglobulins, and susceptibility to infections could suggest this diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation in blood vessels, including symptoms such as erythema, vascular anomalies, and possibly aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes swollen arteries, leading to damage in organs. Symptoms may include aneurysms, skin eruptions like migratory patchy macular erythema, and other vascular problems.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder affecting the body's connective tissue. It can lead to aneurysms (especially in the aorta), and vascular anomalies.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and various symptoms across the body, including skin conditions like erythema and possibly affecting vascular health.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders affecting connective tissues, leading to symptoms including atherosclerosis, vascular anomalies, and possibly aneurysms due to the fragility of blood vessels.

diagnoses.name: Livedoid Vasculopathy
diagnoses.description: A condition leading to blockages in the blood vessels of the skin, causing painful ulcers and potentially migratory patchy macular erythema.

diagnoses.name: Schnitzler's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disease characterized by chronic urticaria, bone pain, and various other symptoms including potential skin lesions similar to migratory patchy macular erythema.

diagnoses.name: Fabry Disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder impacting lipid metabolism, which can cause atherosclerosis, vascular anomalies, and is associated with an increased risk of heart attack and stroke.

diagnoses.name: Takayasu's Arteritis
diagnoses.description: A rare form of vasculitis that damages the large arteries, particularly the aorta and its branches, leading to symptoms such as vascular anomalies and potential aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease of blood vessels (most commonly the temporal arteries) that can cause headaches, jaw pain, vision problems, and could also indirectly contribute to atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: CVID is a disorder characterized by low levels of several immunoglobulin classes, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections. Symptoms can include episodic weakness, infections, and in some cases, gastrointestinal issues such as malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Selective Immunoglobulin A (IgA) Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This is the most common primary immunodeficiency disorder. Individuals may present with recurrent infections, including sinus and lung infections that could explain congestion, and gastrointestinal problems, which may manifest as malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: X-linked Agammaglobulinemia (XLA)
diagnoses.description: This genetic condition mostly affects males, leading to very low levels of immunoglobulins. It can cause recurrent bacterial infections, which may lead to symptoms like episodic weakness and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome (ALPS)
diagnoses.description: ALPS is a disorder of the immune system that can cause excessive production of lymphocytes, leading to lymphadenitis, and can be associated with autoimmune conditions affecting various parts of the body, including the gastrointestinal tract.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD)
diagnoses.description: CGD is a disorder that affects the immune system's ability to fight certain types of infections. Symptoms can include recurrent infections, such as pneumonia (which might present as congestion) and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Hyper IgM Syndromes
diagnoses.description: These are conditions where patients have high levels of IgM but low levels of other types of immunoglobulin. Patients often have recurrent infections, which could contribute to symptoms like congestion and episodic weakness.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: While primarily known for its effect on the digestive system, leading to symptoms of malabsorption, Celiac disease can also affect the immune system and potentially lead to recurrent infections.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Advanced HIV infection can lead to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), characterized by a significant drop in immune cells (CD4+ T cells), leading to decreased immunoglobulins and various infections or associated conditions like lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: This form of tuberculosis affects the gastrointestinal system, potentially causing malabsorption. It can also affect the lymphatic system, leading to lymphadenitis, and impact overall immune function.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis is a disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that can form as nodules in multiple organs. It can impact the lymphatic system, causing lymphadenitis, and affect the lungs, potentially leading to symptoms of congestion.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.reason: Directly matches the symptom of obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.reason: Connective tissue disorders like Ehlers-Danlos can explain symptoms like hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension (High Blood Pressure)
diagnoses.reason: Directly matches the symptom of hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Lymphadenitis
diagnoses.reason: Directly matches the symptom of lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: External Otitis (Swimmer's Ear)
diagnoses.reason: Directly matches the symptom of Otitis externa.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Another connective tissue disorder, potential to explain hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Broad category, could be related to obsessive-compulsive behaviors.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Some autoimmune disorders can lead to symptoms like lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Joint Hypermobility Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Specifically diagnosable condition related to hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Hypertension
diagnoses.reason: Hypertension could be secondary to another condition or symptom within this list.

diagnoses: Psychiatric disorders influencing physical health (such as severe OCD or depression with somatic symptoms)

diagnoses.name: Stress-Induced Cardiomyopathy
diagnoses.details: Also known as Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, it can be triggered by intense emotional or physical stress and presents with symptoms similar to a heart attack.

diagnoses.name: Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A life-threatening reaction to neuroleptic or antipsychotic medications. Symptoms may include muscle rigidity, fever, and autonomic instability.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.details: Overactivity of the thyroid gland leading to a rapid metabolism. Symptoms can include mood lability, weakness, and heart-related issues.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness, spasms, and mood swings.

diagnoses.name: Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A condition associated with episodic muscle weakness, usually linked to an underlying cancer.

diagnoses.name: Primary Dystonia
diagnoses.details: A movement disorder that causes involuntary muscle contractions and spasms, such as blepharospasm.

diagnoses.name: Bipolar Disorder
diagnoses.details: A mental health condition marked by extreme mood swings from mania to depression. Mood lability is a key feature.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A hormonal disorder caused by high levels of cortisol in the blood. Symptoms can include mood swings and metabolic issues such as dyslipidemia.

diagnoses.name: Periodic Paralysis
diagnoses.details: A group of rare genetic disorders that cause episodic muscle weakness or paralysis usually precipitated by triggers like stress, rest after exercise, or changes in potassium levels.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.details: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disorder that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which can be episodic in nature.

diagnoses: Gastrointestinal Disorders causing abdominal cramps (e.g., IBS, Crohn's Disease)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Peptic ulcer disease with complication (e.g., perforation or hemorrhage)
Peptic ulcer disease with complication (perforation or bleeding)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with gastrointestinal and renal involvement

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergy-related condition where the immune system responds to allergens with symptoms like nasal congestion, runny nose, and itchy eyes.

diagnoses.name: Common Cold
diagnoses.description: A viral infectious disease of the upper respiratory tract causing symptoms like runny nose, cough, and sore throat.

diagnoses.name: Influenza
diagnoses.description: A contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses, with symptoms including cough, fever, and runny nose.

diagnoses.name: Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the sinuses leading to symptoms like nasal congestion, facial pain, and a reduced sense of smell.

diagnoses.name: Non-allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the nasal mucosa not caused by allergies. Symptoms include nasal congestion, runny nose, and sneezing.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your airways narrow and swell, producing extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath.

diagnoses.name: COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease)
diagnoses.description: A group of lung diseases that block airflow and make it difficult to breathe, including emphysema and chronic bronchitis.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)
diagnoses.description: An infection in any part of the urinary system, including kidneys, ureters, bladder, and urethra. Symptoms might include urine incontinence but generally do not include rhinorrhea or nasal congestion.

diagnoses.name: Overactive Bladder
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a sudden, involuntary contraction of the muscle in the wall of the urinary bladder, leading to urinary urgency, with or without incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: Also known as eczema, a condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Acute Intoxication (e.g., from allergens or toxins)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) with allergic reaction
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with kidney involvement
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.description: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.detail: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can affect several systems in the body, manifesting symptoms such as angioedema, dyspnea, and abdominal cramping.

diagnoses.description: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.detail: An allergic reaction causing inflammation of the nasal airways, often leading to symptoms like rhinorrhea, pruritis, and can contribute to angioedema.

diagnoses.description: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.detail: A genetic disorder marked by recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema), often along with abdominal cramping and potentially life-threatening airway obstruction.

diagnoses.description: Food Allergy
diagnoses.detail: An adverse immune response to food proteins, causing symptoms ranging from hives, angioedema, dyspnea, abdominal pain, to severe anaphylaxis.

diagnoses.description: Drug Allergy
diagnoses.detail: An immune system reaction to a medication, manifesting as skin reactions, angioedema, respiratory distress, and in severe cases, anaphylaxis.

diagnoses.description: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.detail: A skin rash caused by contact with a certain substance, leading to skin irritation and sometimes systemic reactions like pruritis, angioedema, especially with repeated exposure.

diagnoses.description: Urticaria (Hives)
diagnoses.detail: A skin reaction that produces itchy welts, often associated with angioedema, pruritis, and in some cases, could lead to anaphylactic reactions.

diagnoses.description: Insect Sting Allergy
diagnoses.detail: An allergic reaction to insect venom, which can result in symptoms ranging from local pain and swelling to systemic effects like angioedema, dyspnea, and anaphylaxis.

diagnoses.description: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.detail: A disorder characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin and other parts of the body, leading to symptoms like urticaria, angioedema, dyspnea, and abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.description: Idiopathic Angioedema
diagnoses.detail: Angioedema without an identifiable cause, characterized by recurring episodes of severe swelling in various parts of the body, including the intestinal tract causing abdominal cramps.

diagnoses: Mastocytosis (including Systemic Mastocytosis and Cutaneous Mastocytosis)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Viral Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea or vomiting, and sometimes fever.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in response to an infection or trauma. Symptoms can include headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, neurological deficits, and dysarthria.

diagnoses.name: Medication-induced Nausea
diagnoses.description: Nausea or vomiting caused by side effects of medications.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, characterized by headache, fever, stiff neck, nausea, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, vomiting, difficulty speaking (dysarthria), and other neurological problems.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition in which poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms like speech difficulties (dysarthria), paralysis, and potentially nausea.

diagnoses.name: Chemical Poisoning
diagnoses.description: Exposure to toxic substances can lead to symptoms including nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking (dysarthria), and more severe effects depending on the toxin.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving the central nervous system, potentially leading to symptoms such as fatigue, difficulty speaking (dysarthria), and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Alcohol Intoxication
diagnoses.description: The physiological condition that follows the consumption of alcohol, featuring symptoms like nausea, vomiting, slurred speech (dysarthria), and impaired coordination.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraine with aura includes not only head pain but also a variety of sensory disturbances including scotoma (blind spots), scintillation (flashing lights), and sometimes paresthesia prior to or during the headache.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis can cause dysphagia due to neurological impairment, paresthesia as a common symptom, and in some cases may lead to visual disturbances such as scotomas.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: A TIA or 'ministroke' can present with transient symptoms including headache, paresthesia, and visual disturbances such as scotomas and scintillating scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke may present similarly to a TIA but with potentially longer-lasting symptoms. It can cause dysphagia, paresthesia, and various visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Depending on its location, a brain tumor could cause a wide range of neurological symptoms including dysphagia, headaches, paresthesia, and visual symptoms like scotomas.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve can lead to visual symptoms such as scotoma and, less commonly, headache and neurological symptoms if associated with a broader disorder like multiple sclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: An unruptured cerebral aneurysm might produce headaches and, depending on its location, could affect vision or cause paresthesia by pressing on nearby nerves.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: This condition results from reduced blood flow in the posterior circulation of the brain, potentially causing dysphagia, visual disturbances such as scotoma, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Migrainous Infarction
diagnoses.description: A rare form of migraine that actually involves a stroke occurring during a migraine with aura attack, leading to persistent visual disturbances, paresthesia, and lasting neurological deficits.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: This inflammatory condition affects the arteries and can lead to severe headaches, vision problems like scotomas, and, in advanced cases, stroke-like symptoms such as paresthesia and dysphagia due to affected blood supply.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. Tinnitus, headache, numbness, and phonophobia can all be associated with migraines.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In Meniere's disease, tinnitus and a feeling of fullness in the ear are common symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. Numbness is a common symptom, and some sufferers may experience tinnitus or headaches due to the lesions on their brain or spinal cord.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal cell growth in the brain. Depending on its location, a brain tumor can cause tinnitus, headaches, numbness, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular migraine
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that primarily affects the body's balance system. Alongside traditional migraine symptoms, individuals may experience vertigo, tinnitus, and sensitivity to sound.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety disorders
diagnoses.description: Although primarily psychological, anxiety disorders can manifest physically, causing symptoms like headaches, numbness, tinnitus, and hypersensitivity to noise.

diagnoses.name: Temporal arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of blood vessels, typically in the head, that can cause headaches, jaw pain, and vision problems. Tinnitus can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the cranial nerve that affects balance and hearing. Primary symptoms include tinnitus, hearing loss, and balance issues.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, transmitted by ticks. Symptoms vary widely and can include headaches, facial paralysis, and neuropathy, potentially leading to numbness or tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension (High blood pressure)
diagnoses.description: Though often asymptomatic, severe or uncontrolled hypertension can manifest as headaches, and in some cases, tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. A stroke is a medical emergency, and prompt treatment is crucial. Early action can reduce brain damage and other complications.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Eventually, the disease can cause permanent damage or deterioration of the nerves.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can be cancerous (malignant) or noncancerous (benign). When benign or malignant tumors grow, they can cause the pressure inside your skull to increase. This can cause brain damage, and it can be life-threatening. Brain tumors can develop directly in the brain (primary brain tumors), or cancer can begin in other parts of your body and spread to your brain as secondary (metastatic) brain tumors.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) is a benign tumor that develops on the balance and hearing nerves leading from your inner ear to your brain. The branches of this nerve directly influence your balance and hearing, and pressure from an acoustic neuroma can cause hearing loss, ringing in your ear and unsteadiness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often referred to as a 'mini-stroke,' a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. It’s often a warning sign of a future stroke.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck. Most cases of meningitis in the U.S. are caused by a viral infection, but bacterial, parasitic, and fungal infections are other causes.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body. Guillain-Barre is a medical emergency that requires hospitalization.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease is caused by four main species of bacteria. It is transmitted by the bite of an infected black-legged or deer tick. Symptoms can occur anywhere from 3 to 30 days after the bite and can be wide-ranging, depending on the stage of the infection. In some cases, symptoms can include paralysis or weakness in the limbs, and impaired muscle movement.

diagnoses.name: Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: Otitis media is an inflammation or infection located in the middle ear. Otitis media can occur as a result of a cold, sore throat, or respiratory infection. Symptoms might include hearing loss, but typically it's more common in children.

diagnoses.name: Presbycusis
diagnoses.description: Presbycusis, or age-related hearing loss, is the gradual loss of hearing in both ears. It's a common problem linked to aging. This form of hearing loss tends to occur in both ears and affects them equally. The loss is gradual, so someone with presbycusis may not realize that their hearing is diminishing.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms. Phonophobia (sensitivity to sound) and headache are key features. Some patients may experience transient aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' TIA produces similar symptoms to a stroke (including aphasia and numbness) but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A serious condition where the blood supply to part of the brain is cut off, leading to symptoms like aphasia, numbness, and headache, depending on the area affected.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include numbness, fatigue, and in some cases, hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Ménière's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing severe dizziness (vertigo), ringing in the ears (tinnitus), hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness or congestion in the ear. It sometimes accompanies migraine headaches.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Any intracranial tumor can cause headache, aphasia, numbness, and hearing loss, depending on its location in the brain. Symptoms vary with the tumor's size and location.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma)
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Hearing loss and sometimes headache are typical symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain. Can cause headache, phonophobia, numbness, behavioral changes, and in severe cases, hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Migrainous Infarction
diagnoses.description: A rare type of ischemic stroke occurring during a migraine with aura attack, leading to permanent neurological deficits such as aphasia or numbness.

diagnoses.name: Conversion Disorder
diagnoses.description: A condition in which patients present with neurological symptoms such as numbness, aphasia, or even blindness, without a neurological cause. It's considered a type of somatic symptom disorder.

diagnoses: Viral or bacterial infection affecting the nervous system
Infections causing secondary immunodeficiency and systemic involvement (e.g., HIV)
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Microscopic polyangiitis)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia combined with Immune Thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease can present with neurological symptoms (seizures), renal involvement (proteinuria), and skin manifestations such as non-scarring alopecia and chilblain lupus lesions. Myelitis can also be a manifestation of CNS involvement.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with Secondary Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting joints, RA can lead to vasculitis that may explain symptoms like chilblain and rarer complications like myelitis. Proteinuria might result from amyloidosis secondary to chronic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder that can have neurologic complications (seizures), renal involvement (proteinuria), and is associated with non-scarring alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: An overlap syndrome that can present with signs and symptoms of multiple autoimmune disorders including those affecting the skin (chilblains, non-scarring alopecia), kidneys (proteinuria), and nervous system (seizures, myelitis).

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: A specific manifestation of SLE affecting the kidneys, presenting with proteinuria. Could be associated indirectly with other symptoms due to overall disease activity.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder characterized by thrombosis and miscarriages but can also present with neurological manifestations like seizures. Myelitis can sometimes be a complication.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.rationale: A vasculitis that can cause damage to various organs including the skin (chilblains), kidneys (proteinuria), and occasionally involves the nervous system (seizures, myelitis).

diagnoses.name: Cryoglobulinemic Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Associated with hepatitis C, this vasculitis shows a range of symptoms that could align with the ones described, particularly with renal and skin involvement.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash, but can occasionally have other manifestations such as those described.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, including the brain (which can lead to seizures), skin, and potentially renal involvement.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if not secondary to an autoimmune or systemic disease)
Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Peripheral Neuropathy, Myopathy, Hoarseness, and Hearing Loss Syndrome (PNMHH)
Hepatitis B or C associated cryoglobulinemia
B12 Deficiency or Other Megaloblastic Anemias
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) secondary to Glomerulonephritis
Biopsy-proven Lichen Planus with Neurological Manifestations
Peripheral Neuropathy, Myopathy, Hoarseness, and Hearing Loss (PNMHH Syndrome)
Stevens-Johnson Syndrome/Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis Overlap Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Lupus erythematosus with secondary antiphospholipid syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with synovitis, delirium (as part of neuropsychiatric lupus), non-scarring alopecia, and hemolytic anemia, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Mainly known for causing synovitis, but systemic manifestations can occasionally include anemia, and very rarely, alopecia or neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Known for autoimmune destruction of exocrine glands causing dry eyes/mouth but can have systemic involvement including arthralgia (which may be confused with synovitis), and hematologic abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Some drugs can induce a lupus-like syndrome presenting with symptoms like those of SLE, including arthralgia, non-scarring alopecia, and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.rationale: Primary condition characterized by hemolytic anemia; associated secondary symptoms can sometimes include synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily a hematological disorder but can present with broad symptoms due to hemolysis and bone marrow dysfunction; not typically associated with synovitis or alopecia, making it a less likely but possible differential.

diagnoses.name: Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura
diagnoses.rationale: A rare blood disorder that can cause neurological symptoms (potentially similar to delirium), anemia, but less commonly associated with alopecia or synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Known for causing vascular thrombosis and pregnancy complications but can present with hemolytic anemia and, rarely, neurological manifestations or joint symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: A group of disorders that cause blood vessel inflammation could potentially cover a wide range of symptoms, though specific types like microscopic polyangiitis may be more likely to present with hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV infection can present with a wide array of symptoms, including hematologic abnormalities (like hemolytic anemia), hair loss due to various factors, and joint pain or arthritis.
